question: A 55-year-old male, diagnosed with stage four pancreatic cancer, presents to the clinic with abdominal pain and jaundice for the past 1 week. On examination, he is severely emaciated and jaundiced. Laboratory evaluation reveals total bilirubin is 10.3 mg/dL, direct bilirubin is 9.3 mg/dL, indirect bilirubin is 1.0 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase is 514 mg/dL. What is the management of choice for this patient?
What is the range for food items with a medium glycemic index, such as oranges, or honey?
Which of the following is incorrect regarding abetalipoproteinemia?

answers.option: Dietary restriction of long-chain fatty acids improves symptoms
Low serum cholesterol and low-density lipoproteins

question: A 55-year-old male is brought to the emergency room from his office with a history of vomiting approximately two cups of blood. On examination, he has a grossly distended abdomen with positive fluid thrill. Mild jaundice is also observed. What is the likely complication in this patient?
What laboratory parameter is used to differentiate between biliary colic and acute cholecystitis?
Which of the following is the etiology of Cushing's ulcers?
A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of bloody diarrhea for the past 2 weeks. What is the least important diagnostic investigation in such cases?
Which of the below-enlisted food items may precipitate the clinical features in celiac disease?
Which gene mutation is most commonly associated with gastrinomas?
Which amongst the below enlisted is not included in the Ranson criteria at time of admission?
What is the correct unit for body mass index (BMI)?

A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with increased bloating, abdominal pain, and explosive diarrhea upon ingestion of dairy products for the past several months. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?
What site of the gastrointestinal tract is involved, as a rule, in ulcerative colitis?
What is the most common site involved in Crohn's disease?
What is an important complication of severe ulcerative colitis?
Which benign tumor is characteristically associated with combined oral contraceptive use?
Which of the following is true for the investigations in a case of suspected intussusception?

answers.option: Abdominal radiograph is a first line investigation to confirm the diagnosis of intussusception
At ultrasonography, a doughnut sign on longitudinal section is diagnostic
At ultrasonography, a pseudo kidney sign on transverse section is diagnostic
Ultrasonography can predict irreducibility of intussusception using pneumatic reduction

question: A 60-year-old-female presented with abdominal pain and weight loss. Her ultrasound shows lesions in the liver. What is the next appropriate investigation?
What is the confirmatory test for diagnosis of upper GI bleeding?

A 32-year-old male patient, with a known case of Crohn’s disease, came to the outpatient department (OPD) with complaints of multiple discharging sinuses in the perianal region. What would be the most appropriate radiological investigation to reach the diagnosis in this patient?

A 45-year-old man was diagnosed with hepatitis B infection 2 years ago. Now he came to the outpatient department (OPD) for the follow-up. Recovery from hepatitis B infection is indicated by which of the following negative test?

Three weeks after a meal at a roadside restaurant, a 20-year-old male presents with loss of appetite, malaise, fatigue, and mild yellowness of sclera. Which of the following laboratory test findings is he most likely to have?

A 34-year-old man presents in the gastrointestinal (GI) clinic with abdominal pain, and jaundice. His laboratory investigation confirms that he is positive for hepatitis C infection. Which of the following is true of hepatitis C infection?

answers.option: Persistent infection and chronic hepatitis are the hall marks of the infection
Hepatitis C virus is a DNA virus
Alpha-interferon is an effective treatment to cure the infection

question: A 44-year-old man, an emergency medical technician, has felt fatigued for the past 4 months. On physical examination, there are no remarkable findings. Laboratory studies show his alanine transaminase (ALT) 132 U/L and aspartate transaminase (AST) 113 U/L with total bilirubin 1.3 mg/dL and direct bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL. A liver biopsy is performed, and microscopic examination shows focal necrosis, interface inflammation with the extension of inflammation into the lobules from the triads. There is a ground-glass appearance of hepatocytes. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most characteristic for his disease?

answers.option: Positive anti hepatitis B core antigen
Positive anti hepatitis B surface antigen

question: Treatment for parathyroid hyperplasia is:

A 53-year-old woman presents with complaints of weakness, anorexia, malaise, constipation, and back pain. While being evaluated, she becomes somewhat lethargic. Laboratory studies include a normal chest x-ray, serum albumin 3.2 mg/dL, serum calcium 14 mg/dL, serum phosphorus 2.6 mg/dL, serum chloride 108 mg/dL, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 32 mg/dL, and creatinine 2.0 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

A 43-year-old man has had mid-epigastric pain and nausea for the past 2 months. On physical examination, he has no abnormal findings. On upper GI endoscopy, a solitary sharply demarcated 2-cm shallow gastric antral ulcer is seen. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this man?

A 30-year-old female developed bleeding after excessive bouts of vomiting. The bleeding stopped spontaneously. Upper GI endoscopy showed longitudinal mucosal lacerations in the lower part of the esophagus. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 3-week-old boy is referred for persistent vomiting. He was well until 5 days ago but is now vomiting after each feed, is not putting on weight, and appears jaundiced. After a test, he has a projectile non-bilious vomit. You suspect that he has pyloric stenosis and perform a venous gas and electrolyte analysis. What would you expect the result to reveal

A 50-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease presents with blood in the vomitus. There is no history of NSAIDs or steroid use. On examination, there is splenomegaly, ascites, and caput medusa around the umbilicus. Considering the diagnosis, what will be the best treatment option?

A 13-year-old child with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with intermittent diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting. On examination, he has short stature with anemia, angular stomatitis, and paresthesia. What is the likely clinical diagnosis?
A 22-year-old girl develops severe retching with nausea and vomiting. She later has hematemesis of about 200 ml. Which of the following is the most probable cause of hematemesis?

A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back and left shoulder for 24 hours. He has a history of anorexia and vomiting for two days. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
The gold standard test for diagnosis of celiac disease is:
Methods of investigation of the biliary system do not include:
What is the treatment for grade 3 ascites?
What is the least invasive diagnostic test for gall stones?

A 26-year-old woman has had bloody, mucoid, low-volume diarrhea for the past six weeks. The stool frequency is five per day. She is afebrile, with no abdominal mass or tenderness. Stool examination reveals only mucous and blood with few leukocytes, no ova or parasites seen. Colonoscopy shows a friable, erythematous mucosa extending from the rectum to the middle of the descending colon. Rectal biopsy shows acute mucosal inflammation with cryptitis and crypt abscesses. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

A 27-year-male has a bout of profuse vomiting during a barbecue party. He complains of shortness of breath and severe lower chest pain and upper abdominal pain. On examination, he is tachypneic and tachycardia . There is rigidity of the upper abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 35-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with obstructive jaundice. Her ultrasound showed stones in the common bile duct. What is the best management?

A 38-year-old woman consults you before her planning to spend summer holidays in Gilgit and Swat with her husband and a 12-year-old boy. They never had hepatitis or liver disease in the past and none of them have had immunization against hepatitis. Which of the following plans would you recommend for the family?

answers.option: Hepatitis A vaccination for both parents and child
Hepatitis A vaccination for parents and child and Hepatitis B vaccination for the child
Screen parents for previous Hepatitis A infection, and recommend Hepatitis A vaccination for the child
Screen all members of the family for Hepatitis A and B exposure
Hepatitis A and Hepatitis B vaccination for both parents and the child

question: A 40-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with history of recurrent pain in right hypochondrium. Pain is aggravated with fatty meals. What is the mostly likely diagnosis?

A 43-year-old female develops severe epigastric and penetrating back pain following a dinner party. She was in shock when brought to the hospital. Which one of the following laboratory investigations would be most helpful in early diagnosis?

A 43-year-old man complains of epigastric pain and nausea for 3 months. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Upper GI endoscopy reveals a solitary sharply demarcated 2-cm shallow gastric ulcer at the antrum. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most relevant in this man?
What is the best investigation for a liver abscess?
What is the empirical treatment for diarrhea?
What type of ulcer is found in abdominal tuberculosis?

A 29-year-old woman presents to the emergency with abdominal distension and intense itchiness all over her body. She complains of fatigue for more than a week and soon after the itchiness began. Her alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is 300 U/L and aspartate transaminase (AST) is 95 U/L. What is the diagnostic investigation for her symptoms?

A 38-year-old man presents to the clinic with yellow discoloration of the sclera and skin. He had a transfusion 8 years ago and has had multiple transfusions for various reasons over the past few years. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

A 20-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic with speech impairment, muscle stiffness, and gait abnormalities. An ophthalmic examination revealed a cherry-red spot on the macula. Abdominal examination findings included hepatosplenomegaly. What is the next investiagtion?
A 30-year-old unmarried woman comes into the outpatient department with a complaint of constipation. What is the doctor most likely to recommend for her condition?

answers.option: Tell her to eat more dairy products

question: What aggravates the symptoms of an insulinoma?
What is the treatment for a tumor on the liver that is 2 cm?

A 50-year-old male presents with blood in the vomitus. There is no history of NSAIDs or steroids use. On examination, there is splenomegaly, caput medusa around the umbilicus, and positive shifting dullness. Given this history and examination, what is the most likely cause of upper GI bleeding?

A 50-year-old male presents with his investigations showing HBsAg positive, HBeAg negative, ALT 120 IU/ml, and HBV DNA >10,000 IU/ml. His fibro scan shows an F3 score. What is the best option to start with?
A 50-year-old male presents with heartburn, epigastric pain, and regurgitation for 2 weeks. His examination is unremarkable. What is the treatment of choice?
A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency room with fever, chills & rigors. He has right hypochondrial pain and jaundice. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

A 60-year-old male with small bowel diverticulosis presents with steatorrhea. He undergoes certain investigations including a hydrogen breath test which is positive. Which of the following condition should be considered in this case?
A 60-year-old man with known ulcerative colitis presents with an acutely distended, tender abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A 60-year-old male presents with melena. Which of the following would be the most useful investigation?
What is the most common cause of esophageal variceal bleeding?

A 35-year-old female patient reports having epigastric abdominal pain for the last 7 months and has also lost 10 kg weight during this time. She is currently taking proton pump inhibitors (PPI). What is the next step in management?
Which of the following is used to screen for colorectal carcinoma?
A 37-year-old patient, on steroids for ulcerative colitis, is in sustained remission. He develops central obesity and a moon-like face. What is the next step in his management?
A 21-year-old female presents to the emergency room in an unconscious state. On examination, she has a sweet-smelling odor. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a complaint of recurrent abdominal pain for the last 1 year, mostly in the lower abdomen that is relieved by defecation. He is also giving the history of increased frequency of stools approximately 3-4 times per day. He does not have weight loss & nighttime awakening due to these symptoms. On examination, he is vitally stable. Systemic and general physical examinations are unremarkable. Complete blood count and ESR are normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Which of the following parameters help differentiate between cholelithiasis and acute cholecystitis?
Which of the following is a sign of localized peritonitis?

answers.option: Lack of abdominal movement during respiration

question: Parietal cell antibodies are present in which of the following?

A 39-year-old female comes to the outpatient department with abdominal pain. She has a history of weight loss and jaundice. Labs reveal raised alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and des-gamma-carboxyprothrombin (DCP) levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Adenocarcinoma is associated with which of the following?
What is the name of the sign in which right inferior quadrant (RIQ) pain is elicited by palpation of the left inferior quadrant (LIQ)?

A 32-year-old female presents with an altered level of consciousness and irritability for one day. On examination, she is pale and jaundiced. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg, pulse is 55 beats/min, respiratory rate is 32/min. Tender hepatomegaly is also present. On inquiry, she gives a history of yellow discoloration of sclera & skin for the last 7 days. Lab results show a hemoglobin level of 11.2 gm/dl, total white blood cell count of 12000/mm3, platelet level of 332,000/mm3. Liver function tests show total bilirubin of 15 mg/dl, direct bilirubin of 5 mg /dl, serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase of 3000 IU/L, alkaline phosphatase of 680 IU/L, prothrombin time of 60 sec, and International normalized ratio= 3.5. She is in grade 3 encephalopathy. The most common cause of this presentation will be?
Barotrauma (spontaneous perforation) of the esophagus is classically seen in pressure events when a person strains against a closed glottis during?
How is the immunity towards hepatitis B virus measured?
Which of the following organisms is associated with Reiter's syndrome?
A painless enlarged gallbladder is associated with which of the following diseases?
What is the most common site of peptic ulcer disease?
Which of the following is associated with a low-fiber diet?
In which of the following conditions is misoprostol given?
What is the dietary advice given to a patient with cirrhosis?
A patient has repeated episodes of emesis and epigastric pain upon eating meals and before sleeping. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of heartburn. He is sent for endoscopy which revealed pinkish mucosa on the esophagus near the gastro-esophageal junction. What is the diagnosis?

A female patient comes to the clinic with complaints of diarrhea along with fever and abdominal cramping. Colonoscopy revealed pseudomembrane formation on colonic mucosa. The patient has a history of long-term intake of antibiotics. She still complains of repeated episodes of colitis. The doctor recommends fecal bacterio-therapy. Which one of the following bacteria is most probably involved?
In a 35-year-old male acute pancreatitis is suspected. On taking history it's noted that the patient is an alcoholic. Which single lab investigation will you do to confirm the diagnosis?
Which of these is most likely to cause a palpable gallbladder in a patient with jaundice?

In a patient with pancreatitis, there is inappropriate release and activation of pancreatic enzymes, which destroy pancreatic tissue and cause the release of more enzymes. Which two laboratory blood tests are the most helpful in the evaluation of pancreatitis patients?

The mode of transmission of the hepatitis B virus is different in different parts of the world. Vertical transmission in 90% of cases is seen in high prevalence areas. However high-risk people are recipients of blood transfusions, dialysis patients, health care workers, I/V drug abusers, and homosexuals. Which of the following is the marker of infectivity in both acute and chronic cases of HBV infection?
Regarding carcinoma of the colon, which of these is the most appropriate investigation?
Which form of viral hepatitis is transmitted via contaminated food and water?
Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels are raised in which of the following?

A man at a barbeque party starts vomiting profusely and continuously. He also complains of lower chest and upper abdominal pain, He is taken to the hospital. On examination, tenderness, tachycardia, and hypotension are observed. What is the most likely cause?
Which of the following is correct regarding the tumors of the gall bladder?

answers.option: Squamous cell type of the cancer is the most common
They occur more commonly in males
Infiltrative form of gall bladder cancers is more common

question: A 3-month-old child has acute diarrhea and is irritable. When his skin is pinched it goes down slowly. His mucosal membranes are also seen to be dry. What is the appropriate treatment?

answers.option: Oral rehydration solution 300 ml every 4 hours
Oral rehydration solution 50-60 mg after watery diarrhea

question: A 3-month-old child has acute diarrhea and is irritable. When his skin is pinched it goes down slowly. His mucosal membranes are also seen to be dry. Which of the following corresponds to the condition of this child?
What is the most common cause of acute gastroenteritis in children less than 1 year in age?
What metabolic disorder is seen in gastric outlet obstruction?
Which of the following will be observed on endoscopic biopsy of celiac disease?
Which of the following signs can help confirm appendicitis?
Which of the following is correct regarding hepatorenal syndrome?

answers.option: Laboratory finding consistent with post-renal failure
Diagnosed when serum creatinine < 1.5 despite using diuretics

question: Which of the following is not a risk factor for hepatitis-induced encephalopathy?
A 41-year-old patient presents to the emergency with hyperreflexia. On examination, his GCS score is 12/15. Which of the following is the correct grade of encephalopathy?
Which of the following nonfunctional plasma enzymes is elevated in alcoholics?
Which of the following is the characteristic radiological hallmark of paralytic ileus?
Which of the following statements is true regarding the hepatitis C virus?
Which of the following antibiotics is effective in patients with shigella dysentery?

A 50-year-old truck driver presented to the outpatient department with the complaint of painful perianal swelling for a few months, which bursts on its own but recurs after some days and the wound never heals completely. On further investigation, he also gave a history of fever and pus discharge from the swelling. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with the complaint of bloody diarrhea with stingy mucoid material for 1 year. He also gave a history of lower abdominal cramps that were temporarily relieved by defecation. What is the gold standard test for confirming this disease?
Which of the following organisms would cause diarrhea in a patient with pseudomembranous colitis?
A patient with a duodenal ulcer comes to the clinic with a complaint of blood in vomiting. The ulcer has eroded the posterior wall of the duodenum and ruptured which artery?
What is the prime treatment of ascites secondary to portal hypertension?

A middle-aged female presents to the outpatient department with the complaint of gradual distention of the abdomen for the past 4 months and pedal edema for 3 weeks. There is no history of nocturia or periorbital puffiness. Her abdomen is distended and her spleen is palpable three fingers below the costal margin. Shifting dullness is also positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not a precipitating risk factor for hepatitis-induced encephalopathy?

A young male presents to the emergency department with the complaint of blood in vomiting and an altered level of consciousness since last night. Attendants describe that he had four bouts of large-volume, black-colored vomiting after which he became drowsy. On examination, his blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse is 112 beats per minute, he is drowsy and anemic, and has bipedal edema and clubbing. His abdomen is non-tender with an enlarged spleen and ascites. What is the most likely cause of his bleeding?
Early starvation causes transient changes in basal metabolic rate. With long-standing starvation, which of the following is correct regarding BMR in long-standing starvation?

answers.option: BMR is not affected by dietary changes
BMR decreases in long standing starvation
BMR is not affected by energy expenditure
BMR increases in long standing starvation
BMR is not affected by the nutritional status of an individual

question: A patient presented to the outpatient department with reports that were positive for viral hepatitis. What type of jaundice can be seen in this patient?

answers.option: Jaundice due to sickle cell disease

question: A 40-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with the complaint of aching pain in the abdomen anorexia, weight loss, pale stools, and dark-colored urine. Which of the following symptoms in this patient indicate obstructive jaundice?

A 28-year-old male comes to the outpatient department with a history of colicky abdominal pain for 6 months. Pain is usually associated with diarrhea and abdominal bloating. He denies any history of fever and weight loss. Physical examination is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old female presents to the hospital with loose stools for 3 years. On examination, she is anemic, has glossitis, and marked weight loss. Investigations reveal Hemoglobin (Hb( 9 g/dl, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 70. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy with biopsy shows subtotal villous atrophy with intra-epithelial lymphocyte infiltrates. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not the cause of extreme weakness and malnutrition in liver cirrhosis?

answers.option: Anorexia and liver decompensation leading to poor dietary intake
Metabolic changes characterized by reduced energy expenditure

question: Which of the following options correctly states the management of subacute partial small bowel obstruction?

answers.option: Intravenous hydration, NPO, nasogastric decompression, monitoring

question: A 70-year-old man was brought to the hospital due to his cardiac conditions. Upon history, it was found that he has no physical activity in his daily schedule and oil is often reused in home-cooked food for the cooking. After a detailed examination, the doctor suggested a change in his sedentary lifestyle and dietary habits. The change is necessary to produce which of the following outcomes?

answers.option: To increase free radicals in diet

question: What is true about the oxidative rancidification of oils?

answers.option: Rancid oil has increased omega fatty acids
Oxygen reacts with the unsaturated fatty acids
Carbondioxide reacts with the saturated fatty acids

question: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency with complaints of nausea, and right upper quadrant pain. There is no history of jaundice. Laboratory investigations reveal a total leucocyte count (TLC) of 12,000 cells/dl with 91% neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?

A man presents to the hospital with an altered level of consciousness two hours after falling in the washroom. He has pinpoint pupils with a pulse of 78 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 180/120 mmHg, and a fever of 107°F despite antipyretics. Sponging is also of no use. What is the most likely cause of fever?

A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with generalized abdominal pain and board-like rigidity. He has a history of chronic NSAID use. An abdominal X-ray reveals air under the diaphragm. Which of the following conditions is most likely the cause of this patient's condition?

A 50-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of abdominal pain and yellowing of the sclera. Which of the following is the best first-line investigation to do in this patient?

A 20-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with right upper quadrant pain and pruritis along with severe diarrhea for the past 1 month. A percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram is performed on the patient, which reveals a beaded appearance of the extrahepatic bile ducts. Which of the following is the most likely cause of diarrhea in this patient?
Which of the following is the investigation of choice in a person who developed colonic strictures after a large bowel resection is done due to a colorectal carcinoma?

A 30-year-old male is brought in an unconscious state to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. After regaining consciousness, the patient realizes that he can neither feel nor move his lower limbs. On examination, the gut sounds are absent, and the doctor suspects paralytic ileus. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?

A 63-year-old male, who is a heavy smoker, complains of food sticking behind his sternum for the last 5 months. He has lost considerable weight and appears malnourished. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and biopsy confirm the malignant growth. What should be assessed first before commencing the therapy?

answers.option: CT scan of abdomen and chest

question: Apart from ammonia, which of the following substances also accumulate in the blood in case of acute liver failure?

A 30-year-old man presented to his primary care physician the results of his recent screening, which he did for an overseas job. The lab shows the presence of Anti- Hepatitis C antibody. Which of the following further tests should be advised?

A 20-year-old man presented to the medical specialist with complaints of yellow discoloration of the eyes for one week. Along with this, he complained of a fever and vomiting. He has a history of using un-boiled water. Which of the following initial tests should be ordered?

answers.option: LFT and Serological Test for Hepatitis A & E

question: A 45-year-old man presents to the family physician with complaints of pain in the abdomen, especially in the right hypochondriac region. The pain has been associated with high-grade fever for 7 days. Ultrasound abdomen shows a liver abscess size of 10 cm x 8 cm. What treatment is recommended for his illness?

answers.option: Surgical resection of the liver abscess

question: A 16-year-old boy arrived at the medical emergency department with loose motions for six months. On examination, he appears frail and malnourished. His complete blood count (CBC) reveals HB 5 g/dl, MCV 60 fl, platelet counts 5 lacs, and WBC 4000/cubic mm. Which of the following tests is recommended to diagnose the cause of his diarrhea?

answers.option: Serum celiac disease panel (anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies)

question: A 20-year-old man presents to the medical OPD with complaints of diarrhea, and abdominal cramps for two days. They are watery in consistency and associated with blood in stool. On examination, he has a pulse of 100/min, a B.P. of 100/70 mm temperature of 101°F, and looks dehydrated. Which of the following is the most likely organism causing his illness?

A 38-year-old female patient with gestational amenorrhea for 32 weeks presents in the ER with a sudden development of jaundice followed by an altered level of consciousness. On examination, she is hemodynamically stable, and deeply jaundiced, but not oriented in time, place, and person. LFT shows marked Increased serum bilirubin with a marked increase in ALT, and AST levels. Which of the viral infections is more likely to be the cause of her rapid deterioration?

A 42-year-old male, smoker, obese, came to a gastroenterologist with a recurrent history of epigastric pain and retrosternal burning not responding to conventional treatment, taken for the last 4-6 weeks. He planned an upper GI endoscopy which showed reddish longitudinal lesions extending above the Z-line, and multiple biopsies were taken. Biopsy showed Columnar metaplasia in the esophagus. What is the diagnosis?
An old man presented to the outpatient department with shortness of breath, palpitations, and slight chest pain. Which of the following types of activity should be recommended to him?
Which of the following tests is advised to a patient with shrunken, nodular liver and hypersplenism?
A female who is a known case of hypertension visited a nutritional consultant. Which of the following diets would the consultant recommend for this patient?
Which of the following is the Rockall score used for?
Which of the following differentiates between femoral and inguinal hernia?
Which of the following can be given in acute liver failure?
A 45-year-old patient presents with a mass in the liver, which appears as an anechoic lesion on ultrasound. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient presents with RLQ pain that initially started around the umbilicus. His Alvarado score is 5–6. What is the next best step in management?

A 45-year-old man with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus (HbA1c: 9.2%), obesity (BMI: 32 kg/m²), and hypertension (140/85 mmHg) presents with fatigue, right upper quadrant discomfort, and nausea. He has no history of alcohol use. Examination reveals mild hepatomegaly without jaundice or stigmata of chronic liver disease. Ultrasound shows increased liver echogenicity, consistent with fatty infiltration. Laboratory findings include mildly elevated AST (55 U/L) and ALT (75 U/L), along with dyslipidemia (total cholesterol: 230 mg/dL, triglycerides: 220 mg/dL). Given these findings, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

answers.option: Recommend weight reduction and lifestyle modifications
Encourage moderate alcohol intake to reduce fibrosis risk
